description: v3-12 'Coverage Expansion': 454 existing + 54 new models from 4 sector deep dives (Accommodation/Food, Transportation, Construction, Admin/Support). Covers 50M+ additional workers (30% of US employment). VCR v2 fundamental scoring with independent capture/velocity analysis. All 508 models ranked on Transformation, Opportunity, and VC ROI.

SN.name: Structural Necessity
SN.description: Must this business exist given structural forces?

FA.name: Force Alignment
FA.description: How many F1-F6 forces drive it, weighted by velocity?

EC.name: External Context
EC.description: How much does international context materially change viability vs. US-only assessment?

categories.STRUCTURAL_WINNER: SN >= 8.0 AND FA >= 8.0 — must-exist business with multi-force convergence
categories.FORCE_RIDER: FA >= 7.0 — rides 3+ converging macro forces (and not STRUCTURAL_WINNER)
categories.TIMING_ARBITRAGE: TG >= 8.0 AND SN >= 6.0 — narrow entry window
categories.CAPITAL_MOAT: CE >= 8.0 AND SN >= 6.0 — cash-flow positive within 6 months
categories.FEAR_ECONOMY: Arises from fear friction: macro_source contains 'fear' or sector fear_friction_gap > 3
categories.EMERGING_CATEGORY: Doesn't map to existing NAICS or macro_source contains 'emerging'
categories.CONDITIONAL: Composite >= 60 but no other category matched (fallback)

notes: Models can have MULTIPLE categories assigned as a list
primary_category is the first matched in priority order
GEOGRAPHIC_PLAY removed — replaced by EC axis, no equivalent category
Batch normalization applied: v3-2_cycle (SN -1.5, FA -1.5, TG -2.5), new_macro_45 (SN -0.5, FA -0.3, TG -0.5)

MO.name: Market Openness
MO.description: How open is this market to new entrants? Measures current concentration, entry barriers, and trend direction.

scale.1-2: Monopoly/duopoly (>80% top-2 share), regulatory capture, structural barriers
scale.3-4: Oligopoly (3-5 players dominate), high capital/regulatory barriers
scale.5-6: Concentrated but with viable entry paths, moderate barriers
scale.7-8: Fragmented market, many players, low structural barriers

MA.name: Moat Architecture
MA.description: How fragile are incumbent moats? Higher = more fragile = better for entrants.

scale.1-2: Network effects + data moat + regulatory capture (nearly unbreakable)
scale.3-4: Strong data or network effects with some cracks
scale.5-6: Moderate moats (brand, scale) that technology could erode
scale.7-8: Weak moats primarily from switching costs or legacy relationships
scale.9-10: No meaningful moats, or moats about to be disrupted by technology shift

VD.name: Value Chain Depth
VD.description: How many independent defensible positions exist in the value chain? More layers = more ways to enter and differentiate.

scale.7-8: Multiple entry points at different stack levels, each independently viable
scale.9-10: Deep multi-layer stack where entrants can own unique positions

DV.name: Disruption Vectors
DV.description: How many plausible mechanisms exist that create openings for new entrants? Includes technology shifts, regulatory changes, incumbent weaknesses.

scale.1-2: No credible disruption path; incumbents have locked in
scale.3-4: Theoretical disruption but requires massive capital or rare conditions
scale.5-6: 1-2 plausible disruption paths actively in play
scale.7-8: Multiple disruption vectors simultaneously opening the market
scale.9-10: Incumbent position actively eroding from multiple simultaneous vectors

categories.WIDE_OPEN: OPP >= 75 — nascent/highly fragmented, no meaningful incumbents, multiple entry paths
categories.ACCESSIBLE: OPP >= 60 — fragmented with breakable moats, viable entry strategies exist
categories.CONTESTED: OPP >= 45 — incumbents exist but real disruption vectors create openings
categories.FORTIFIED: OPP >= 30 — strong incumbents with real moats, limited entry paths, niche-only
categories.LOCKED: OPP < 30 — monopoly/duopoly with structural moats, entry requires 100x capital

cla_system.dual_ranking_principle: Transformation Rank (5-axis composite) and Opportunity Rank (CLA composite) are independent analytical systems that sit side by side. They are NEVER merged into a single number. High Transformation + Low Opportunity = 'will happen but you can't play it.' Low Transformation + High Opportunity = 'accessible but may not materialize.' The most actionable models score high on BOTH dimensions.

MKT.name: Market Magnitude
MKT.description: Realistic capturable market in 3-5 years. Not hand-waving TAM but plausible revenue ceiling for a single company.

scale.7-8: $2-10B realistic addressable, multiple paths to $500M+ revenue

CAP.name: Capture Feasibility
CAP.description: Can a seed-funded startup realistically capture meaningful share in 3-5 years? Measures actual capture mechanics, not hype.

scale.1-2: Incumbents own distribution, 24+ month sales cycles, regulatory blocks
scale.5-6: Mixed channels, some accessible, 6-12 month sales cycles
scale.7-8: Direct acquisition viable, PLG possible, 3-6 month cycles
scale.9-10: Greenfield with pull demand, viral/PLG, customers actively seeking

ECO.name: Unit Economics
ECO.description: Steady-state margin and capital efficiency. Architecture-driven — maps business model to known margin profile.

scale.5-6: Mixed model, 45-60% gross margins, some recurring revenue
scale.7-8: Software/SaaS, 65-80% gross margins, strong unit economics
scale.9-10: Pure software/data, 80%+ margins, near-zero marginal cost

VEL.name: Revenue Velocity
VEL.description: Speed from $0 to $5M ARR. Determines whether 3-5 year window produces markable outcome.

scale.1-2: 36+ months to first material revenue, deep-tech R&D
scale.3-4: 18-36 months, long enterprise sales or regulatory approvals
scale.5-6: 12-18 months, standard B2B SaaS sales cycle
scale.9-10: <6 months, viral/PLG with instant activation, pull demand

MOA.name: Moat Trajectory
MOA.description: Once you have traction, does the business get harder or easier to compete with? Measures 5-year defensibility arc.

scale.1-2: Commodity forever, anyone can replicate, no switching costs
scale.3-4: Moderate switching costs, relationship moat only
scale.5-6: Meaningful switching costs + some data effects, but displaceable
scale.7-8: Strong compounding moat — data flywheel, regulatory capture, multi-product lock-in
scale.9-10: Winner-take-most dynamics, data moat grows exponentially

granularity_framework.trigger: FORTIFIED/LOCKED + VD >= 4 + (T_rank <= 50 OR sector_emp >= 1M OR (T_comp >= 75 AND OPP <= 45))
granularity_framework.method: Value chain layer analysis with Independently Viable Business Test
granularity_framework.scoring: FA/EC inherited from parent; SN/TG/CE re-scored; CLA fully independent

models.name: Retail Media Network Platform
models.one_liner: Advertising platform built on retailer first-party data, transforming retail from margin business to media business. $69.3B market in 2026, growing 20% annually. Amazon (77% share) + Walmart Connect ($4.4B) dominate.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US retail media spending: $58.8B (2025) to $69.3B (2026), growing 20%/year. Amazon Ads at $56B, 77% market share. Walmart Connect $4.4B, up 27% YoY, +53% globally with Vizio acquisition. Retail media fundamentally changes retail economics: stores and logistics operate at near break-even, advertising generates profit margin. This is why Amazon can undercut on price -- they monetize traffic, not products. Mid-market retailers building their own networks (Kroger Precision Marketing, Target Roundel).
models.macro_source: F1: AI-powered ad targeting on first-party retail purchase data. F4: Advertising dollars shifting from social media to retail media where purchase intent is directly measurable.

cla.rationale: Amazon controls 77% of retail media ($56B). First-party purchase data + retailer exclusivity = near-unbreakable moat. Enabling tech layer (Criteo, CitrusAd, Kevel) exists but is thin and commoditizable. Google Ads could aggregate mid-market but doesn't solve the retailer-owned data problem. Entry limited to ad-tech tools, not the network itself. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [54.0 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.

vcr.rationale: Retail media $69B+ but Amazon controls 77%. Massive market, near-impossible capture at seed stage.

models.name: Retail Media Measurement & Attribution Platform
models.one_liner: Cross-channel retail media ROAS measurement, incrementality testing, and media mix modeling platform that helps brands prove ROI across 50+ retail media networks. Addresses the #1 pain point (86% critical priority) in a $71B retail media market with no dominant solution.

cla.rationale: MO=7: No dominant player in independent retail media measurement. Skai, Pacvue, Profitero, Analytic Index, Improvado all compete but none exceeds 15% share. Market is fragmented with many small players. MA=8: Incumbent moats are weak. Existing tools are aggregation dashboards, not AI-native measurement platforms. No network effects or data moats at the measurement layer — brands can switch measurement vendors without switching ad platforms. VD=4: Within measurement itself, sub-layers exist (attribution modeling, incrementality testing, media mix modeling, competitive benchmarking) but these are features of a platform, not independently viable businesses. Moderate depth. DV=7: Multiple disruption vectors: (1) AI-native measurement replacing rules-based attribution; (2) privacy regulation making current tracking-based measurement obsolete; (3) retail media fragmentation (50+ networks) creating urgent demand for cross-network measurement that no incumbent provides; (4) cookie deprecation forcing new measurement paradigms.

vcr.rationale: Measurement/attribution for 50+ retail networks. $2-3.5B TAM, fragmented, SaaS margins. Fast sales.

models.name: Warehouse Fulfillment Robotics Platform
models.one_liner: End-to-end warehouse automation (goods-to-person robots, automated sorting, AI pick-path optimization) for retail fulfillment centers. $181B market by 2031 at 31.6% CAGR.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Retail robotics growing from $20.1B (2024) to $181.1B (2031) at 31.6% CAGR. Symbotic acquired Walmart's Advanced Systems division for $200M. Humanoid robotics funding up 300% (v38-S40). AMR/AGV market $13.2B by 2026. NVIDIA Jetson T4000 ($1,999) makes robot compute cheaper than smartphones. Alibaba open-sourced RynnBrain VLA model (v38-S06). Physical AI is the next major platform after software AI.
models.macro_source: F1: Robotics + AI convergence (Symbotic $200M Walmart deal, NVIDIA Jetson T4000 at $1,999). F2: Labor shortage in warehouse roles. F4: $700B hyperscaler capex creating logistics infrastructure demand.

cla.rationale: Amazon Robotics (ex-Kiva) and Symbotic (Walmart) dominate. Capital + IP + installation lock-in form hard moats. Multi-layer stack (hardware AMR/AGV, pick-path AI, integration, maintenance) provides entry points. Humanoid robotics (Unitree, AgiBot, Figure) is a real disruption vector but 3-5 years from warehouse deployment. Open-source robot brains (Alibaba RynnBrain VLA) could democratize software layer. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [50.5 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.

vcr.rationale: Warehouse robotics $181B by 2031 but requires massive capex. Hardware margins. Not seed-fundable at core.

models.name: AI-Powered Cloud Compliance & Accreditation Automation Platform
models.one_liner: Automated FedRAMP ATO, CMMC, and NIST compliance management platform that reduces accreditation timeline from 18 months to 90 days for DIB companies and federal contractors.

cla.rationale: MO=7: Market fragmented — Drata and Vanta dominate SOC2 but government compliance (FedRAMP/CMMC) is underserved by AI-native tools. Coalfire, Schellman are assessment firms not platform companies. RegScale and Secureframe early but no dominant player. MA=7: Incumbent moats are weak — Drata's SOC2 automation doesn't transfer to CMMC Level 3 which requires fundamentally different control frameworks. No network effects. Switching costs moderate (compliance documentation is portable). VD=4: Within compliance automation, value chain is relatively flat — control mapping, evidence collection, continuous monitoring, assessment management. Fewer independent layers than full classified cloud. DV=8: CMMC enforcement deadline is a regulatory forcing function. AI can automate 80%+ of compliance documentation vs. manual. Legacy GRC tools (Archer, ServiceNow GRC) are heavyweight and expensive, creating opening for specialized vertical SaaS. 15-20% DIB exit rate means surviving companies desperately need efficient compliance.

vcr.rationale: Cloud compliance automation. FedRAMP/CMMC/NIST from 18mo→90 days. SaaS, regulatory moat.

models.name: AI-Native Warehouse Orchestration Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered multi-robot fleet coordination, dynamic path planning, digital twin simulation, and real-time task allocation software for warehouses deploying heterogeneous automation (AMRs + pick arms + conveyors + humanoids). The 'brain' that makes diverse robots work together.

cla.rationale: MO=5: Manhattan Associates ($1B+) and Blue Yonder ($3.1B, Panasonic-owned) are formidable WMS incumbents with deep warehouse operator relationships. SAP and Oracle have large enterprise footholds. However, AI-native orchestration (multi-robot coordination, real-time re-planning, digital twin) is genuinely new and incumbents are playing catch-up. Market is concentrated for traditional WMS but more open for AI-native orchestration. MA=5: WMS incumbents have moderate moats — deep integrations with existing warehouse systems, long sales cycles that favor incumbents, and data from years of warehouse operations. But their moats are in TRADITIONAL WMS functionality, not in AI orchestration. A pure-play AI-native entrant could bypass legacy WMS competition by targeting the orchestration layer specifically. VD=4: Within orchestration, sub-layers exist: path planning, fleet management, demand forecasting integration, digital twin, task allocation. Some of these (digital twin specifically) could be independent businesses. Moderate depth. DV=6: Disruption vectors: (1) heterogeneous automation creating demand for vendor-neutral orchestration; (2) AI foundation models enabling better real-time planning than rules-based WMS; (3) warehouse complexity exceeding human management capacity; (4) WMS incumbents' legacy architecture making AI integration slow and costly.

vcr.rationale: Warehouse orchestration software. Multi-vendor robot coordination. Pure SaaS, data moat.

models.name: Defense Manufacturing Compliance Platform (CMMC + ITAR + AS9100)
models.one_liner: Unified compliance platform for defense manufacturers: CMMC 2.0 + ITAR + AS9100 + NADCAP in one system, targeting 220K+ DIB companies
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW 2023: 3364 aerospace has 4,259 establishments, 536,766 workers at $119,482 avg pay (+7.5% employment growth). CMMC 2.0 enforcement begins 2026. 220K+ DIB companies must certify. Defense spending: $961.6B DoD + EUR 800B ReArm Europe. $13.4B AI/autonomy line. MC-DEF-011 (CMMC Compliance Automation) scored 82.5 (top 5 all-time). Counter-UAS $7.5B budget. Defense tech exits $54.4B > investment $49.1B (Deployment phase). ITAR violations carry criminal penalties up to $1M per violation and 20 years imprisonment.
models.macro_source: CMMC 2.0 enforcement begins 2026, 220K+ DIB companies must certify. Defense spending $961.6B + EUR 800B ReArm Europe. Compliance stack is THE moat in defense manufacturing. MC-DEF-011 (CMMC) scored 82.5 -- extending to manufacturing-specific compliance.

cla.rationale: Defense manufacturing compliance is a moat with multiple reinforcing layers: CMMC 2.0 (cybersecurity, 220K companies must certify), ITAR (export control, criminal penalties), AS9100 (quality management), NADCAP (special process certification). No existing platform integrates ALL of these for SMB defense manufacturers (4,259 aerospace establishments, thousands more in supporting NAICS codes). The opportunity is a unified platform that reduces compliance cost from $50-200K/yr (consultants + manual processes) to $10-30K/yr (automated + continuous). MO is 6 because general CMMC tools exist, but manufacturing-integrated compliance is greenfield.

vcr.rationale: Defense manufacturing compliance SaaS. 220K suppliers. CMMC+ITAR+AS9100.

models.name: AI Governance and Compliance Operating System
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform managing AI model inventory, risk assessment, bias monitoring, and regulatory compliance across US/EU/China regimes.
models.key_v3_context: The $86B fear economy (F5) has its most structured component in AI governance ($309M -> $15.8B = 51x). EU AI Act creates a HARD DEADLINE (Aug 2026) for compliance. Three diverging regulatory regimes (US, EU, China) make cross-jurisdictional compliance complex and valuable. This is fear-as-market-creator: the 46% adoption plateau and enterprise caution DRIVE demand for governance tools. v2 had one governance model (MC-52-003) in financial services only — this is the horizontal, cross-sector version.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + EU AI Act

cla.rationale: Market is nascent ($309M→$15.8B projected, 51x). No dominant AI-native governance platform exists. Legacy compliance tools (ServiceNow, IBM) haven't pivoted to AI governance. Three diverging regulatory regimes (US/EU/China) prevent single-winner dynamics and reward specialized expertise. EU AI Act deadline (Aug 2026) is a hard forcing function. Fear-driven demand (46% adoption plateau) CREATES market rather than just filling it.

vcr.rationale: AI governance platform. Enterprise compliance, growing regulatory push, but immature buying process.

models.name: CMMC Compliance Automation Platform for Defense Contractors
models.macro_source: defense_deep_dive
models.category_rationale: Composite 82.5 >= 80.0 but SN 8.5 < 9.0 per HARD ENFORCEMENT threshold. CMMC is mandatory for defense contractors but not the broader economy — this prevents SN from reaching 9.0. Reassigned from STRUCTURAL_WINNER to FORCE_RIDER. This is the strongest FORCE_RIDER in the entire batch and would rank top 8 in the full 293-model inventory.

cla.rationale: 220K+ Defense Industrial Base companies need CMMC 2.0 certification. Market is fragmented — PreVeil, Coalfire, Forcepoint are early but no one dominates. FedRAMP certification is both a barrier and a moat for first movers. CMMC enforcement deadline is a hard forcing function creating urgent demand. Tool + platform + managed service layers are all viable entry points.

vcr.rationale: CMMC compliance SaaS. 220K DIB companies, regulatory cliff 2026. High urgency, high margins.

models.name: AI Code Quality and Security Audit Platform
models.one_liner: Platform providing automated security auditing, code review, and quality assurance for AI-generated code, addressing the 'trust gap' as 82% of developers use AI coding tools
models.macro_source: P-036 Anticipatory Displacement + 5132 Baumol 2.76 + AI coding 82% adoption

cla.rationale: Market growing 40%+ annually. Snyk, Veracode, Checkmarx exist but are scan-based, not AI-native. 82% of developers now use AI coding tools, creating massive new attack surface that legacy tools can't audit. IDE plugins, CI/CD integration, enterprise dashboards, remediation — multiple layers. No dominant AI-native code audit platform exists yet.

vcr.rationale: AI code quality/security audit. 82% devs use AI tools. Growing WITH AI adoption. Pull demand.

models.name: Semiconductor Test & Packaging Services Platform
models.sector_name: Semiconductor and Other Electronic Component Manufacturing
models.one_liner: AI-optimized semiconductor test and advanced packaging facility serving CHIPS Act fabs -- the capacity bottleneck behind the fab buildout
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW 2023: 3344 (semiconductor equipment/components) has 6,907 establishments, 395,312 workers at $143,228 avg pay. CHIPS Act: $32.5B in grants, $380B+ private investment. 500K jobs across 140 projects. TSMC Arizona ($65B), Intel Ohio ($32B). BUT: 85%+ of global OSAT in Asia. NVIDIA CoWoS packaging bottleneck drives $500B+ orders. Advanced packaging market $44B (2025) growing to $85B+ (2030). Amkor is only major US-based OSAT, primarily operating in Asia. National security case for domestic OSAT is strong.
models.macro_source: CHIPS Act: $630B+ invested, 500K jobs, 140 projects. But fabs produce wafers -- test & packaging (OSAT) is the bottleneck. 85%+ of global OSAT capacity is in Asia. Reshoring test/packaging is the next CHIPS Act wave.

cla.rationale: This is the structural bottleneck behind the CHIPS Act buildout. TSMC Arizona and Intel Ohio fabs will produce wafers, but 85%+ of test and packaging capacity is in Asia. AI-optimized test (reducing test time and cost per die) plus advanced packaging (chiplets, 2.5D/3D integration) are the highest-value portions of the semiconductor supply chain after design and fabrication. Capital barriers are HIGH (MO=5) and incumbents are entrenched (MA=4), but the STRUCTURAL NECESSITY is extreme: you cannot have a domestic semiconductor supply chain without domestic OSAT. CHIPS Act Round 2 funding will target this.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=physical_production_ai, buyer=enterprise, frag=5, tam_source=parsed $500000M

models.name: AI-Native Data Center Operations Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform automating data center operations (cooling, power, workload scheduling) to achieve 15-25% efficiency gains at 95%+ occupancy rates
models.macro_source: P-038 AI Infrastructure Chain Constraint + F6 energy constraints + 518 employment +4.08%

cla.rationale: Schneider Electric, Vertiv, Siemens have existing DC management tools. But AI-native optimization is genuinely new. 1,000+ smaller DC operators in US are underserved by hyperscaler-grade tools. Energy constraints (F6) force adoption. AI itself demands more DC capacity, creating recursive demand. Best entry through mid-market DCs not served by existing vendors.

vcr.rationale: AI-native data center ops. $30B+ market. SaaS but enterprise sales cycle.

models.name: Robot Fleet Operations & Predictive Maintenance Platform
models.one_liner: Cloud SaaS platform for monitoring, predictive maintenance, performance optimization, and lifecycle management of warehouse robot fleets across multi-vendor deployments. Addresses the $8.7B+ automation maintenance market as robot populations scale to 50K-100K humanoid units plus millions of AMRs.

cla.rationale: MO=8: No dominant standalone robot fleet management platform exists. OEMs bundle basic monitoring but it's single-vendor and primitive. The multi-vendor, AI-powered fleet management market is greenfield. Predictive maintenance platforms (Augury, Uptake) exist for industrial equipment broadly but are not robot-fleet-specific. MA=8: No meaningful moats exist yet. OEM bundling is weak (operators want vendor-neutral tools). No network effects yet (fleet management data is per-customer, not cross-customer). First mover could build data advantage from fleet performance data across many deployments, but this moat doesn't exist yet for anyone. VD=3: Within fleet management, sub-layers (monitoring, predictive maintenance, performance benchmarking, lifecycle planning) are features of a platform, not independent businesses. Shallow value chain. DV=7: Disruption vectors: (1) multi-vendor robot deployments creating demand for vendor-neutral fleet management; (2) humanoid deployment wave creating massive new fleet management demand; (3) IoT/predictive maintenance becoming standard expectation; (4) OEM-bundled tools being single-vendor and inadequate for complex deployments.

vcr.rationale: Robot fleet maintenance SaaS. $8.7B market. Predictive maintenance + fleet mgmt. High margins, recurring.

models.name: Retail Data Clean Room & Privacy-Safe Collaboration Platform
models.one_liner: Privacy-safe data matching infrastructure enabling brands and retailers to collaborate on audience targeting and measurement without exposing raw customer data. $2B market (2025) growing to $10B by 2033 as retail media demands privacy-compliant data collaboration.

cla.rationale: MO=6: LiveRamp/Habu is the early leader after acquisition, but market is still forming. Snowflake, AWS, Google all have clean room products — no single dominant player. WPP acquired InfoSum, creating another competitor. Market fragmented enough for new entrants but consolidating. MA=7: Incumbent moats are moderate. LiveRamp has identity graph advantage but clean room interoperability standards are emerging (reducing lock-in). Cloud platforms (AWS, Snowflake) have distribution advantage but not clean-room-specific moats. No dominant data network effect yet — each retailer-brand pair is a distinct relationship. VD=3: Within clean rooms, the value chain is shallow — identity resolution, computation engine, policy enforcement, reporting. These are features of a platform, not independent businesses. DV=8: Strong disruption vectors: (1) Privacy regulation forcing adoption (GDPR, state laws, cookie death); (2) retail media fragmentation requiring neutral data collaboration infrastructure; (3) open-source privacy-preserving computation could democratize the technology layer; (4) cloud platform commoditization of basic clean room functionality pushes value to vertical specialization; (5) clean room consolidation (Habu, InfoSum acquired) creates market gaps as independents disappear.

vcr.rationale: Retail data clean rooms. $2B→$10B by 2033. Privacy regulation tailwind. Platform moat.

models.name: Autonomous Drone Swarm Command Platform
models.one_liner: Software platform for orchestrating autonomous drone swarms in ISR and logistics, selling to NATO allies as SaaS-on-SIPR.
models.key_v3_context: P-030 identifies $2.72T global defense spend growing +9.4% real. DoD dedicated $13.4B AI/autonomy line. NATO 5% GDP target by 2035 creates $500B+ annual increase. Ukraine proved autonomous swarms are the defining weapon system. v2 had ZERO defense models because NAICS-by-NAICS scanning missed this cross-cutting military demand.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle

cla.rationale: Defense procurement barriers, security clearances, ITAR restrictions severely limit entry. Anduril, Shield AI, L3Harris dominate. Classified tech and government relationships are hard moats. Commercial drone tech is cheaper and evolving faster — Ukraine conflict proves smaller companies can compete. AUKUS opens allied markets. Best entry through NATO allies or specific subsystems.

vcr.rationale: Autonomous drone swarms. Massive defense TAM but procurement barriers kill seed-stage capture.

models.name: Cybersecurity AI for Defense Networks
models.one_liner: AI-powered network defense and threat hunting platform purpose-built for CMMC 2.0 compliance across the 300K+ Defense Industrial Base.
models.key_v3_context: CMMC 2.0 mandate creates a hard deadline forcing 300K+ defense contractors to upgrade cybersecurity. This is regulatory-created demand that intersects with F3 (defense spending supercycle) and F5 (fear of cyberattack drives budget). The $60.6B cyber market within the fear economy (F5) has its largest growth vector in defense. v2 had generic cybersecurity models but none targeting the DIB-specific CMMC compliance wedge.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle

cla.rationale: Cyber market broadly is crowded (CrowdStrike, Palo Alto dominate enterprise). But defense-specific AI-native cybersecurity is less crowded. CMMC certification creates barrier-as-moat. Expanding attack surface + AI-generated attacks require AI defense. Defense budgets growing.

vcr.rationale: Defense cybersecurity. Big TAM but procurement kills velocity and capture.

models.name: AI Jobsite Safety Monitoring Platform
models.one_liner: Computer vision + wearable IoT platform that detects safety hazards in real-time (fall risk, PPE compliance, struck-by exposure) on construction jobsites -- addressing the $4.6B construction worker safety market by 2030 within the broader $24.3B AI in construction market
models.macro_source: F1: AI safety/risk management fastest-growing AI-in-construction segment at 30.5% CAGR through 2030. Construction worker safety market: $3.2B (2024) to $4.6B (2030). OSHA reporting ~1,000 construction fatalities/year and 200K injuries. GlobeNewswire Sept 2025, Grand View Research.

cla.rationale: Construction safety is the strongest demand signal in contech -- OSHA fines doubled in 2023, EMR (experience modification rate) directly impacts insurance premiums and bidding eligibility. Newmetrix (acquired by Oracle 2023) and Smartvid.io (acquired by Newmetrix) validated the category. Current leaders include Versatile (crane monitoring), Triax (wearables), and various startups. Market openness is moderate-high because no single platform dominates across all safety vectors (fall protection, struck-by, PPE, housekeeping, trenching). Oracle/Newmetrix is enterprise-focused. The mid-market (200K+ firms) is largely unserved. Demand visibility is the highest of any construction AI category: every GC faces OSHA compliance, insurance pressure, and moral obligation.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction is the deadliest major industry: 1,056 fatalities in 2023 (BLS), 200K+ non-fatal injuries. OSHA's 'Fatal Four' (falls 33.5%, struck-by 11.1%, electrocution 7.0%, caught-in/between 5.4%) are all detectable by computer vision. OSHA maximum penalties increased to $16,131 per serious violation and $161,323 per willful violation (2024 adjustment). The construction worker safety market: $3.2B (2024) to $4.6B (2030) at 6.0% CAGR (GlobeNewswire/ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific safety solutions growing at 30.5% CAGR within this market (Grand View Research). Insurance incentive: a single fatality costs $5M+ in direct costs; EMR impacts persist for 3 years on all bids. AI safety platforms (camera-based + wearable) can reduce recordable incidents 40-60% based on pilot data from Newmetrix, Smartvid.io, and Suffolk Construction deployments. Pricing: $2-5K/month per active jobsite for camera-based monitoring, $5-15/month per wearable per worker.
models.falsification_criteria: If Oracle/Newmetrix integrates comprehensive safety AI into standard Aconex/Primavera bundles at no additional cost. If construction firms refuse to deploy cameras on jobsites due to union resistance or privacy concerns. If OSHA relaxes enforcement under deregulatory political environment, reducing compliance pressure. If wearable IoT fatigue sets in (workers refuse to wear devices).

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.6B (construction worker safety technology by 2030, AI-specific segment ~$1.8B)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Mid-market opportunity is strong: Oracle/Newmetrix serves enterprise GCs, leaving 200K+ mid-market firms underserved. Insurance companies are potential distribution partners (reduced EMR = reduced premiums = shared savings). Path to $150M ARR serving 5,000 jobsites at $30K/year average.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $12K-$120K per firm (scaled by number of active jobsites). Hardware cost: $2-5K per jobsite for cameras. Wearables: $200-500 per unit. Gross margins 65-75% (hardware drag). Payback: one prevented serious injury ($50K+ direct cost) justifies annual subscription.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-60 days for mid-market (safety is urgent, not strategic). Insurance partnership channel accelerates adoption. OSHA citation is often the trigger event. Seasonal: Northern US jobsites slower in winter.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Computer vision models trained on millions of construction-specific images (PPE detection, fall zone identification, equipment proximity). Incident database creates predictive capability (which site conditions predict injuries). Integration with insurance carriers creates switching costs.

models.name: Infrastructure Inspection AI & Drone Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered drone and sensor platform for bridge, road, and utility infrastructure inspection -- replacing dangerous manual inspections in the $38.2B drone inspection market by 2030, with the US infrastructure backlog creating $2.6T in needed repairs (ASCE)
models.macro_source: F1: AI + drones replacing manual infrastructure inspection. F3: IIJA allocates $110B for roads/bridges, requiring inspection at scale. Drone inspection market: $16.4B (2024) to $38.2B (2030) at 15.1% CAGR (ResearchAndMarkets). AI in drones: $821M (2025) to $2.75B (2030) at 27.4% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets).

cla.rationale: Infrastructure inspection is the strongest convergence point in construction: (1) IIJA mandates inspection of 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges, (2) manual inspection is dangerous (inspector fatalities, lane closures causing accidents), (3) inspector workforce is aging and shrinking, (4) drone + AI technology is mature enough for deployment. Current players: DroneUp, Skydio (raised $750M, US-made drones for defense/infrastructure), Flyability (confined space), Gecko Robotics (wall-climbing robots for utilities), and various DOT-specific solutions. Market openness is moderate: Skydio dominates the hardware layer for US government use (Chinese drone ban benefits US manufacturers). The AI ANALYSIS layer (identifying cracks, corrosion, deformation from drone imagery) is where the value concentrates and where competition is fragmented. Demand visibility is extreme: $2.6T infrastructure backlog (ASCE 2025 Report Card) + IIJA spending mandate.

models.deep_dive_evidence: US infrastructure condition: ASCE 2025 Infrastructure Report Card grades US infrastructure C- overall, with $2.6T investment gap. 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges (7.5% of total). 40% of roads in poor or mediocre condition. 7,500 dam safety deficiencies. IIJA: $110B for roads and bridges, $55B for water, $65B for broadband -- all requiring inspection capacity. Current manual bridge inspection: $5-25K per bridge, requires lane closures (costing $50K+/day in economic impact), and exposes inspectors to fall risk. Drone inspection: $1-5K per bridge, no lane closure, higher-resolution data capture. Global drone inspection and monitoring market: $16.4B (2024) to $38.2B (2030) at 15.1% CAGR (ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific drone analysis: $821M (2025) to $2.75B (2030) at 27.4% CAGR. The FAA BVLOS (beyond visual line of sight) waiver program is expanding, enabling autonomous long-range inspections. Skydio's $750M raise and US government contracts validate the hardware layer. The AI layer (automated crack detection, corrosion measurement, structural deformation analysis) is where the most defensible value lies -- each inspection adds training data that improves detection accuracy.
models.falsification_criteria: If FAA restricts BVLOS drone operations beyond current waiver programs. If state DOTs resist drone inspection due to liability concerns (who is responsible if a drone-inspected bridge fails?). If manual inspection workforce expands through immigration or training programs, reducing cost pressure. If Skydio or DJI builds the AI analysis layer into their platforms, commoditizing the software.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.2B (US infrastructure inspection services addressable by drone + AI, within $38.2B global drone inspection market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: US has 617,000 bridges, 4.2M miles of roads, 91,000 dams, 2.6M miles of pipeline -- all requiring periodic inspection. Path to $200M ARR by serving 500 state/municipal DOT contracts at $200K average + 2,000 utility/pipeline contracts at $50K average.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Per-inspection: $1-5K (bridge), $500-2K (road segment), $2-10K (dam). Subscription: $50K-$500K/year per DOT or utility. Gross margins 60-70% (drone hardware and operator costs). Multi-year government contracts provide revenue visibility.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: IIJA funding creates 5-year demand window. Federal mandate: all bridges inspected every 2 years. State DOT procurement cycles: 6-18 months but once won, multi-year contracts. Emergency inspection demand after weather events.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: AI models trained on millions of infrastructure images (crack detection, corrosion grading, deformation measurement). Government security clearance and compliance (NDAA-compliant hardware). Historical inspection baseline database. Integration with DOT asset management systems.

vcr.rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=autonomous_systems, buyer=enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $2600000M

models.name: Warehouse Piece-Picking Robotics Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered robotic arms with multi-modal grippers for individual item picking in fulfillment centers. Addresses the hardest unsolved problem in warehouse automation — handling diverse SKUs in unstructured bins. $1.7B market (2025) growing at 53% CAGR to $14.7B by 2030.

cla.rationale: MO=6: No single dominant player. Righthand Robotics, Covariant, Dexterity.ai, Berkshire Grey, plus emerging Chinese players all compete. Rockwell's investment in RHR creates a funded competitor but not a market closer. Market is concentrated enough (5-8 serious players) to not be wide open, but open enough for new entrants with superior AI. MA=7: Incumbent moats are moderate-to-weak. IP in grasp planning and vision AI is defensible but the underlying foundation models (vision transformers) are commoditizing. Each deployment generates proprietary pick data (training advantage), but the moat is fragile — a better AI model trained on synthetic data could leapfrog real-world training data. No network effects. VD=3: Within piece-picking, the stack is shallow — vision system, grasp planner, robot arm, gripper, cloud analytics. These are components of an integrated system, not independent businesses. DV=7: Multiple disruption vectors: (1) foundation vision-language-action models (Covariant Brain, Alibaba RynnBrain) could democratize the AI layer; (2) commoditization of robot hardware (NVIDIA Jetson T4000 at $1,999 for compute); (3) humanoid robotics potentially subsuming dedicated pick arms (5-year risk); (4) open-source robot brains enabling smaller players to compete on integration rather than AI development.

models.name: AI-Native Restaurant Operating System
models.one_liner: Unified AI-powered back-office platform for independent restaurants — scheduling, inventory, accounting, vendor management in one system targeting the $14.7B restaurant management software market by 2030
models.macro_source: Grand View Research restaurant management software forecast; QCEW NAICS 7225 (10.95M workers, 611K establishments, $26K avg pay); NRA operator surveys 2025

cla.rationale: Toast dominates restaurant tech at 120K+ locations but charges $69-$165/mo per terminal plus payment processing — leaving massive room for AI-native challengers that compress multiple point solutions. Market Openness is moderate (6): Toast, Square, Clover have distribution but independents remain deeply underserved (only 38% use digital ordering). Moat Advantage is strong (7): data compounding across scheduling, inventory, and accounting creates switching costs once embedded — the restaurant OS becomes the system of record. Value Density is moderate (5): $200-400/mo ARPU from small restaurants with high churn (56-day avg employee tenure mirrors owner turnover). Demand Visibility is proven (9): 611K restaurants with <$3K/year tech spend is the most visible unmet demand in any sector. The gap between chain sophistication and independent capability is the largest technology adoption gap in the US economy.

models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data confirms 610,970 restaurant and eating places establishments (NAICS 7225) employing 10.95M workers at $502/week ($26,097 annual) — a Baumol score of 0.36, the lowest in the economy. Grand View Research projects the restaurant management software market reaching $14.7B by 2030 from $5.79B in 2024 (17.4% CAGR). The core thesis: independent restaurants (90%+ of establishments) spend less than $3,000/year on technology versus chains spending $15,000-50,000+/year per location. This $12-47K gap per location across 550K+ independents represents a $6.6-25.8B annual technology spend gap. Toast proved the category ($1.2B+ revenue) but charges payment processing spreads on top of SaaS fees — the AI-native entrant can offer a unified OS (scheduling via AI demand prediction, inventory via computer vision waste tracking, accounting via transaction auto-categorization, vendor management via price comparison) at lower total cost by monetizing the software layer rather than payment spreads. The 2022-2023 QCEW data shows establishments growing 2.5% YoY while employment grows 3.5% — new restaurants are opening and hiring, validating continued demand. Average workers per establishment of 17.9 means the buyer is a small-business owner who needs simplicity, not enterprise features.
models.falsification_criteria: Toast achieves 60%+ penetration of independent restaurants (currently estimated at ~15-20%), eliminating the addressable gap. OR independent restaurant failure rate exceeds 80% in first 3 years (currently ~60%), making the customer base too volatile for SaaS economics. OR LLM costs fail to decline, making AI-native features uneconomical at $200-400/mo price points.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $14.7B (restaurant management software by 2030, Grand View Research). US-specific serviceable addressable: $4.8B based on 600K+ independents at $8K/year average technology spend potential.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can capture 2-5% of US independent restaurants in 5 years (12,000-30,000 locations) at $3,600/year ARPU = $43-108M ARR. This is achievable given Toast's 120K location trajectory from 2017-2026. PLG motion with free tier possible for smallest restaurants.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: Software-only model targets 75-80% gross margins versus Toast's ~22% gross margin on payments. At $300/mo ARPU, LTV of $3,600 (assuming 12-month avg retention for independents, improving to 24+ months for multi-unit). CAC of $800-1,200 via digital + restaurant supply channel partnerships. LTV:CAC of 3-4.5x.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fast adoption cycle: restaurant owners make technology decisions in 1-4 weeks (not enterprise 6-12 months). Monthly billing reduces commitment friction. COVID permanently shifted owner willingness to adopt digital tools. 73% of operators cite labor as #1 challenge — any tool that reduces scheduling pain has immediate pull demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding: once the system tracks scheduling patterns, inventory usage, vendor pricing, and financial performance, switching costs increase monthly. Integration with POS/payment/delivery platforms creates ecosystem lock-in. Network effects emerge if vendor marketplace is built (restaurants collectively negotiate better food prices).

models.name: Skilled Trades Workforce Marketplace & Upskilling Platform
models.one_liner: Two-sided marketplace connecting 2M+ specialty trade workers with 540K contractor firms, with embedded skills verification, credential management, and AR-powered upskilling -- addressing the 650K worker shortage in a $130B temporary staffing market where 17.2% of gig workers are in construction
models.macro_source: F2: 650K unfilled construction positions, 77% of firms report hiring difficulty (AGC 2025). F3: Immigration enforcement constraining 24% foreign-born workforce. CSIS analysis: US needs 140K additional electricians, HVAC techs, equipment operators by 2030. Global temp staffing market $130B by 2030 (Spherical Insights).

cla.rationale: No dominant digital marketplace exists for construction labor. Current solutions: (1) Traditional staffing agencies (Tradesmen International, $1.5B+ revenue; PeopleReady) -- high-fee, low-tech. (2) Workrise (formerly RigUp, $500M+ raised) -- primarily oil & gas, expanding to construction. (3) Instawork, Wonolo -- general gig, not construction-specific. (4) Hireup (construction-focused, early). The gap is a construction-native platform with: credential verification (licenses, OSHA cards, drug tests), skill-matching (an electrician is not a plumber), project-based scheduling (not gig-by-gig), and embedded upskilling (AR training for new certifications). Market openness is high because traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup and the 'Uber for construction workers' has not been built. Demand visibility is the highest possible: 650K unfilled positions is not a forecast, it is a measured gap.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction workforce crisis by the numbers: 650K+ unfilled positions (Feb 2026 estimate based on AGC survey + BLS JOLTS data). 77% of firms report difficulty filling hourly craft positions (AGC 2025 Workforce Survey). Average construction worker age 42.5 and rising. Net annual deficit: ~100K workers/year (retirements exceed new entrants). 24% of construction workforce is foreign-born (Pew Research), concentrated in residential (30%+) -- directly exposed to immigration enforcement. Electrician shortage: 80K+ nationally (IBEW). HVAC technician shortage: 45K+. CSIS (Jan 2026): US needs 140K additional skilled trade workers by 2030 just for clean energy and data center construction. Traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup; digital marketplace could reduce to 15-20% while improving matching speed from days to hours. Credential management is a massive pain point: the average specialty contractor carries 15-25 different licenses, certifications, and insurance documents that must be current for each project. An integrated marketplace with embedded credential verification, AI skill-matching, and AR upskilling modules creates a 3-sided platform (workers, contractors, training providers).
models.falsification_criteria: If immigration policy reverses and labor supply expands rapidly, reducing the shortage below 300K. If Workrise successfully pivots from oil & gas to dominate construction labor. If construction workers prove unwilling to adopt a platform-mediated work model (preferring direct relationships and word-of-mouth hiring). If unions block marketplace models as circumventing collective bargaining agreements.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $22B (construction segment of US temporary/contract staffing, growing at 9% CAGR)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Construction staffing is ~$22B of the $130B US temp staffing market. Platform take rate 12-18% vs traditional agency 30-50%. Path to $500M GMV / $75M revenue in 5 years by serving 50K active workers. Network effects: worker density in a metro creates contractor liquidity.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: GMV per placement: $3-8K/week. Platform take rate: 12-18%. Revenue per active worker: $2-4K/year. CLTV/CAC ratio needs to exceed 3x. Worker acquisition via trade schools, unions, immigration services. Contractor acquisition via demonstrated fill rates.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fastest adoption where shortage is most acute: electricians, HVAC, data center trades. Sales cycle: 1-7 days (contractors need workers NOW). Seasonal variation but data center and infrastructure provide year-round demand.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Worker credential database (verified licenses, certifications, drug tests, safety records). Network effects (more workers attract more contractors attract more workers). Training content library for upskilling. Reputation/rating system creates trust layer that word-of-mouth lacks.

cla.rationale: RegTech market fragmented. No dominant AI-native compliance platform for broker-dealers/RIAs. Legacy compliance tools (NICE Actimize, Broadridge) are heavyweight, not AI-native. SEC/FINRA enforcement increasing. 80% of compliance work automatable. AI can monitor 100% of communications vs legacy 2-5% sampling — 20-50x coverage advantage.

vcr.rationale: Securities compliance automation. 4K broker-dealers. SEC regulatory tailwind. SaaS with regulatory moat.

models.name: Autonomous Trucking Middleware Platform
models.one_liner: Full-stack software platform connecting autonomous truck OEMs with fleet operators and shippers -- orchestrating L4 truck dispatch, handoff zones, and mixed fleet management in the $42.9B autonomous truck market growing to $86.8B by 2032
models.macro_source: Aurora Innovation surpassed 250K driverless miles Jan 2026, guiding $14-16M 2026 revenue with 200+ trucks by year-end. Mordor Intelligence: autonomous truck market $39.5B (2025) to $65.7B (2030) at 10.7% CAGR. Fortune Business Insights: $42.9B (2025) to $86.8B (2032). L4 driver-out pilots surged 140% YoY in 2025. ATA: 60K driver shortage growing to 160K by 2028.

cla.rationale: The autonomous trucking stack has three layers: (1) AV technology (Aurora, Waymo, Kodiak -- $5-15B invested per company); (2) OEM integration (Paccar, Daimler, Volvo); (3) fleet orchestration middleware (relatively greenfield). Layer 1 is locked by billion-dollar incumbents. Layer 3 -- the middleware that lets a fleet operator run a mixed fleet of human-driven and autonomous trucks, manage transfer hub handoffs, and optimize AV utilization -- is the opportunity. MO is 5 because Aurora and Kodiak are building their own fleet management tools, but a neutral middleware platform serving multiple AV providers and multiple fleet operators creates network effects. MA is 7 because integration depth with each AV stack creates switching costs. VD is 9 because per-mile pricing on $875B US trucking market yields massive value density.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Aurora Innovation: $3M 2025 revenue, guiding $14-16M 2026, targeting $80M run-rate by end 2027. 250K+ driverless miles by Jan 2026, nearly 3x Oct 2025. 200+ driverless trucks by end 2026. Second-gen hardware kit mid-2026 cuts costs 50%, doubles lidar range to 1,000m. Kodiak: $770K Q3 revenue, 92.5% YoY growth, military contracts for autonomous logistics. US trucking: $875B revenue, 3.58M drivers, 60K shortage growing to 160K by 2028. L4 deployment reality: highway hub-to-hub corridors (Dallas-Houston, Phoenix-El Paso) first, urban later. Transfer hubs needed every 200-400 miles for driver handoff. Mixed fleet management is the transition-period software problem: most fleets will run 10-30% autonomous, 70-90% human for 5+ years. Whoever builds the orchestration layer for this transition captures the operating system of autonomous freight.
models.falsification_criteria: If Aurora, Kodiak, and Waymo all vertically integrate fleet orchestration (refusing to work with third-party middleware), the neutral platform thesis collapses. If L4 deployment delays beyond 2028 due to regulatory or technology failures, the TAM timeline extends dramatically. If autonomous trucks achieve >90% utilization without transfer hub complexity (highway-only routes with no handoff), the orchestration middleware is less valuable.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $4.5-8B by 2030 (middleware layer capturing 5-10% of autonomous trucking operating costs on $65-87B total market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible but requires deep integration partnerships with AV providers. Neutral positioning (working with Aurora AND Kodiak AND Waymo) is the moat, but each AV company will resist third-party fleet management. Most likely path: win with mid-size carriers first (500-5000 trucks) who cannot afford to build their own AV integration stack.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS + per-mile transaction fee model. Target $0.03-0.05/mile on autonomous miles (vs driver cost of $0.45-0.65/mile saved). Gross margins 70-80% once platform built. But development costs are high ($20-50M to build credible AV integration layer).
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-12 months for fleet operators. Pilot deployments start small (5-20 trucks). Full deployment ramp 18-36 months per customer. Fastest adoption in hub-to-hub truckload corridors where AV utilization is highest.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Multi-AV-provider integration depth (API integrations with Aurora, Kodiak, Waymo are each 6-12 months of engineering). Fleet operator switching costs increase with data accumulation (route optimization, load matching, maintenance scheduling). Network effects: more carriers on platform = better load matching for autonomous trucks.

models.name: AI Construction Project Management Copilot
models.one_liner: AI copilot for construction project managers that automates scheduling, RFI processing, submittal tracking, and daily reports -- targeting the $11.6B construction management software market growing to $19.1B by 2030 at 12.1% CAGR
models.macro_source: F1: AI-driven progress analytics expanding at 14.12% CAGR through 2031, outpacing traditional PM modules. F2: 650K unfilled positions mean PMs are overloaded, managing 2-3x project volume vs 2019. Mordor Intelligence Construction Management Software Market Report 2025.

cla.rationale: Market openness is moderate because Procore ($1.31B revenue, 16K+ customers), Autodesk Construction Cloud, and Oracle Aconex dominate the GC/owner segment. However, AI-native copilot features are nascent -- Procore just launched basic AI in 2025. The opportunity is to build an AI-first PM tool for the underserved mid-market (sub-$50M projects, 90%+ of market by volume) where Procore is too expensive ($10K-$50K/year) and Excel/paper still dominates. Moat builds through project data accumulation: each completed project trains the model on scheduling patterns, delay causes, cost escalation factors. Value density is high -- construction PM software yields $8K-$50K ACV per GC. Demand is proven: 70% of construction projects run over budget, 80% run over schedule.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The construction management software market reached $10.64B in 2025 and is projected to grow to $19.12B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence, 12.08% CAGR). Cloud solutions lead with 62.35% market share. AI-driven progress analytics is the fastest-growing segment at 14.12% CAGR. Currently, 70% of construction projects exceed budget and 80% exceed schedule. The average construction project overrun is 16% on cost and 20% on time (McKinsey Global Institute). Procore dominates large GCs but only serves ~16K customers out of 814K+ employer construction firms -- 98% of the market is unserved by modern PM software. Mid-market GCs and specialty contractors manage projects via spreadsheets, email, and paper. An AI copilot that automates RFI processing (avg 200+ RFIs per commercial project), submittal tracking, daily report generation, and schedule optimization could reduce PM labor by 30-40% per project while improving on-time/on-budget rates. At $500-$2,000/month per project (10-20x cheaper than Procore for small firms), the addressable mid-market is $3-5B.
models.falsification_criteria: If Procore's AI features mature rapidly enough to serve the mid-market at lower price points (watch for Procore pricing tier below $500/month). If construction firms prove fundamentally unwilling to adopt AI PM tools (adoption stays below 10% through 2028). If the economic necessity argument weakens -- construction slowdown reduces project volume, easing PM workload pressure.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $5.2B (AI-specific PM tools within $19.1B total construction software market by 2030)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup can capture mid-market segment underserved by Procore/Autodesk. 800K+ firms with no modern PM software. Path to $100M ARR serving 10K firms at $10K ACV. Competing against spreadsheets and paper, not Procore.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $6K-$24K depending on firm size. Gross margins 80%+. CAC challenge is high (fragmented market, low digital engagement). Field sales required for larger GCs. Product-led growth possible for sub-10 employee firms.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 30-90 days for small firms, 6-12 months for mid-market GCs. Seasonal demand (construction is seasonal in northern US). Network effects: GCs pull subs onto platform for document sharing.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Project data compounding (scheduling patterns, cost databases, risk models trained on thousands of completed projects). Integration with BIM tools and accounting systems. Workflow lock-in once adopted mid-project.

models.name: Warehouse Robotics Orchestration Layer
models.one_liner: Multi-vendor warehouse robotics orchestration software managing AMRs, pick systems, and conveyors from multiple vendors in the $6.5-17.6B warehouse robotics market growing at 19-23% CAGR to $17-56B by 2030-2033
models.macro_source: Fortune Business Insights: warehouse robotics $6.5B (2025) to $25.4B (2034). Grand View Research: $4.3B (2022) to $17.3B (2030) at 19.6% CAGR. Straits Research: $17.6B (2025) to $55.7B (2033). GM Insights: $14.7B (2024), 23.1% CAGR to 2034. 26% of US warehouses now use some form of automation. Warehouse worker turnover 43%. Average warehouse wage $44K -- labor shortage is structural.

cla.rationale: Warehouse automation has dozens of hardware vendors: AMRs (Locus, 6 River/Ocado, Geek+), AS/RS (AutoStore, Swisslog), goods-to-person (Symbotic, Berkshire Grey), palletizing (Covariant, RightHand). Each has proprietary control software. The ORCHESTRATION problem: a large warehouse (500K+ SF) typically has 3-5 different robotic systems from different vendors that cannot communicate. The middleware/orchestration layer that manages multi-vendor robotics (task allocation, traffic management, slotting optimization) is the unseized opportunity. SVT Robotics raised $25M for exactly this but market is early. MO is 6 because warehouse management system (WMS) vendors (Manhattan Associates, Blue Yonder) are expanding into robotics orchestration. MA is 7 because deep integration with each robot vendor's API creates compounding switching costs.

models.deep_dive_evidence: 1.8M US warehouse workers, employment doubled since 2015. 26% of warehouses use automation but 74% still primarily manual -- massive adoption headroom. Average warehouse handles 3,000-10,000 SKUs; e-commerce warehouses handle 50K-500K SKUs (complexity drives automation need). Symbotic: $1.8B backlog, Walmart-exclusive initially but expanding. Locus Robotics: 95M+ units picked via AMRs. AutoStore: 1,200+ installations globally. Key pain: a warehouse running Locus AMRs, AutoStore cube storage, and conveyor sortation has THREE separate control systems. Workers must mentally bridge the gaps. Orchestration software that unifies these systems can improve throughput 20-35% based on early deployments. SVT Robotics (SOFTBOT Platform) is the earliest mover but raised only $25M. The market needs what Kubernetes did for cloud: a multi-vendor orchestration standard for warehouse robotics.
models.falsification_criteria: If a single robotics vendor (Symbotic, Amazon Robotics) achieves dominant market share and imposes its own orchestration standard, multi-vendor orchestration becomes niche. If Manhattan Associates or Blue Yonder successfully adds robotics orchestration to their dominant WMS platforms, standalone orchestration loses the market to platform incumbents. If warehouse operators prefer single-vendor solutions (simplicity over best-of-breed), the multi-vendor orchestration use case shrinks.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $2.5-5B by 2030 (orchestration software layer capturing 15-20% of warehouse robotics spend as software-to-hardware ratio increases)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible targeting large 3PLs and enterprise warehouses (500K+ SF) with multi-vendor robotics installations. Must support minimum 5 major robot vendors at launch. First-mover advantage significant because integration depth compounds. SVT Robotics is the reference startup but underfunded relative to opportunity.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing per robot managed: $200-500/robot/month. Large warehouse with 200 robots = $40-100K/month. Gross margins 80%+. Implementation services ($50-200K per warehouse) provide initial revenue. Annual contract value $500K-1.2M per large warehouse.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-12 months for enterprise warehouses. Proof of concept with 1 building, expand to multi-site. Fastest adoption at 3PLs who operate multiple client warehouses and need standardized multi-vendor management. Peak season performance (Q4) is the decision driver.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Integration depth with each robot vendor (6-12 months API work per vendor). Data compounding: task allocation algorithms improve with more throughput data. Network effects among 3PL operators: a 3PL running 50 warehouses standardizes on one orchestration platform. Robot vendor partnerships: becoming the recommended orchestration layer for Locus, AutoStore, etc.

models.name: Energy Code & Sustainability Compliance Platform for Construction
models.one_liner: AI platform automating energy code compliance, LEED/WELL certification documentation, and embodied carbon tracking for new construction -- targeting the $17.5B building code compliance market by 2032 where 70% of firms already use software for green certification and energy codes are tightening 15-25% per cycle
models.macro_source: F6: IECC 2024 requires 15-25% energy improvement. 9 states mandate heat pumps. Building sector = 40% of US energy consumption. F1: AI automates energy modeling and code checking. Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032), 8.8% CAGR (Coherent Market Insights). Green construction market growing at 11.2% CAGR.

cla.rationale: Energy code compliance is increasingly mandatory and increasingly complex. Current tools: (1) EnergyPlus (DOE, free, complex), (2) REScheck/COMcheck (DOE, basic compliance), (3) IES VE, eQUEST (commercial energy modeling, $10K+/year), (4) Autodesk Insight (integrated with Revit but limited), (5) cove.tool ($30M raised, performance-based building design). No single platform connects energy code compliance to permit submission to sustainability certification to embodied carbon tracking. The fragmentation of energy codes across jurisdictions (some states on IECC 2021, others on 2024, California on Title 24) creates complexity that AI can simplify. 70% of firms in developed regions already use software for green building compliance -- the question is whether a new platform can consolidate the workflow. Demand visibility is high: every new building must comply with energy codes, and codes are tightening every 3 years.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Building sector consumes 40% of US energy. Building codes are the primary policy lever for reducing building energy consumption. IECC 2024 (adopted by 12 states as of Feb 2026) requires 15-25% energy improvement over 2021 baseline, including: mandatory blower door testing, continuous insulation, high-efficiency HVAC, and for commercial buildings, automated lighting controls and energy recovery ventilation. California Title 24 (2025 cycle) mandates all-electric new construction in many zones. NYC LL97 imposes carbon penalties on existing buildings >25,000 SF starting 2024 (up to $268/ton CO2). 9 states mandate heat pumps in new residential. Embodied carbon: Portland, Vancouver, and LEED v5 now require lifecycle carbon assessment of construction materials. Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR. Green building certification market growing at 11.2% CAGR. cove.tool ($30M raised) has proven the 'performance-based design' category. The integration opportunity: a single platform that (1) identifies applicable energy codes by jurisdiction, (2) runs automated energy modeling on building designs, (3) checks compliance and generates required documentation, (4) tracks embodied carbon in material selections, (5) generates LEED/WELL/ENERGY STAR documentation. For residential builders (1.1M workers, 225K firms), energy code compliance is the FASTEST-GROWING source of project complexity and delay.
models.falsification_criteria: If political backlash halts energy code tightening (building code adoption is state-level; conservative states may freeze at IECC 2021 or earlier). If Autodesk integrates comprehensive energy code compliance into Revit/ACC at no extra cost. If embodied carbon regulation stalls at pilot-city level without scaling. If builders bypass energy codes through loopholes rather than adopting compliance software.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $3.2B (energy code compliance + green certification + embodied carbon software within the $17.5B broader code compliance market)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Target: 200K+ residential builders + 50K commercial builders needing energy code compliance. Path to $100M ARR by serving 15K builder firms at $6.5K ACV. Regulatory mandate creates non-optional demand. Code tightening every 3 years creates recurring upgrade cycles.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $3K-$15K per builder depending on volume. Per-project pricing also possible ($200-$1K per energy model). Gross margins 80%+. CAC moderate: code officials and building departments are referral channels. Energy raters and HERS providers are channel partners.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: New code adoption cycles create demand spikes. California Title 24 and NYC LL97 are early indicators of national trend. Builder association partnerships provide channel. Every new project is a potential sale.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Jurisdiction-specific code database (energy codes vary by state, county, and city). AI energy modeling trained on thousands of building types and climate zones. Integration with BIM tools and permit submission systems. Green certification workflow automation.

Market openness moderate because Verkada, Rhombus, and Coram.ai are funded incumbents. But moat advantage is HIGH because AI model quality compounds with deployment scale — more cameras = better anomaly detection = fewer false alarms = lower monitoring costs. Value density is very high: enterprises spend $50-200K/year on security per location. A $5-15K/year AI monitoring subscription replaces 2-3 guards ($100-150K annual cost). Demand visibility is proven — every commercial building, retail store, warehouse, and campus needs security monitoring. The 1.1M guard workforce at 200-300% annual turnover creates chronic labor shortage that PUSHES adoption.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The US security guard services industry employs 1.1M workers at $35K average pay ($38.5B annual payroll) with the highest turnover rate of any sub-sector (200-300% annually per ASIS International). The AI video surveillance market was $6.5B globally in 2024 and is projected to reach $28.8B by 2030 at 30.6% CAGR (Grand View Research), with North America holding 33.6% share ($9.7B by 2030). Verkada raised $200M Series E at $4.5B valuation (Feb 2025), proving venture-scale economics. The company reports 20,000+ customers across 70+ countries. Cloud-based security represents a fundamental shift: traditional security requires on-premise NVR hardware ($10-50K), dedicated monitoring staff ($40-60K/year), and physical guard presence ($35-50K/year per guard). AI monitoring platforms reduce this to $200-500/camera/year with superior detection accuracy. Verkada's AI can detect people, vehicles, license plates, and unusual behavior patterns. SIA (Security Industry Association) reports that AI-driven systems account for roughly one-third of new security deployments in 2025, up from <10% in 2022. The physical security services market stands at $119.2B globally in 2025 (Mordor Intelligence). Key growth driver: commercial real estate owners facing CMBS delinquency pressure (12.34% record) are cutting guard contracts and replacing with camera-based monitoring to reduce operating costs 60-80% per monitored zone.
models.falsification_criteria: Model invalidated if: (1) AI false alarm rates remain above 20% by 2028, preventing trust-based guard replacement; (2) Regulation requires physical human guard presence for certain facility types (some jurisdictions already mandate this for schools/hospitals); (3) Verkada or similar player achieves >40% market share, closing the window for new entrants; (4) Liability concerns prevent enterprises from replacing guards with cameras (wrongful-death lawsuits when AI misses threats).

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $9.7B US AI video surveillance market by 2030 (North America 33.6% of $28.8B global). Broader addressable: $38.5B annual guard payroll that can be partially converted to technology spend.
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible in SMB and mid-market segments that Verkada under-serves. Verkada focuses on enterprise (avg deal $50K+). Massive long tail of 500K+ commercial properties spending $5-25K/year on security that need simpler, lower-cost AI monitoring. Regional integrators (50K+ in US) are the distribution channel.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS model: $200-500/camera/year. At 50 cameras per customer, $10-25K ACV. 85%+ gross margins on software. Hardware margins 30-40% if bundled. Customer payback: replacing one security guard ($35-50K/year) with 10-20 AI cameras ($2-10K/year total) delivers 5-15x ROI in year one.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Fast adoption cycle: 2-4 week deployment (cloud-based, no on-premise servers needed). Security turnover crisis accelerates adoption — when a customer can't hire guards, they buy cameras. Commercial real estate cost pressure (CMBS delinquency) creates urgency. Insurance premium reductions for AI-monitored facilities create financial incentive.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding: more deployed cameras = better AI models = fewer false alarms = lower monitoring cost = more deployments. Network effects within multi-site customers (retail chains, property managers). Switching costs moderate (camera hardware lock-in). Channel relationships with 50K+ security integrators create distribution moat.

models.name: Construction Digital Twin & BIM Intelligence Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered digital twin platform that converts BIM models into living project replicas with real-time progress tracking, clash detection, and lifecycle management -- serving the $15.4B BIM market by 2030 and $155B digital twin construction market
models.macro_source: F1: BIM market growing from $9.0B (2025) to $15.4B (2030) at 11.3% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). Digital twin in construction projected to reach $155B by 2030 at 19.0% CAGR. Federal BIM mandate expanding to all projects >$5M.

cla.rationale: Autodesk (Revit, ACC) and Bentley Systems dominate BIM authoring. But the AI layer -- converting static BIM into living digital twins with computer vision progress tracking, automated clash detection, and predictive analytics -- is nascent. Doxel (YC, $45M raised) and OpenSpace ($116M raised) lead AI progress monitoring but haven't closed the BIM-to-twin loop. The opportunity is the INTEGRATION layer: connecting BIM design data to field reality via computer vision, IoT sensors, and AI analytics. Moat advantage is high because training data (thousands of project scans correlated with outcomes) creates compounding accuracy. Value density is strong: $50K-$500K per project for large commercial/infrastructure.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The BIM market is valued at $9.04B (2025) growing to $15.42B by 2030 (MarketsandMarkets, 11.3% CAGR). Digital twin in construction: $64.9B (2025) to $155.0B (2030) at 19.0% CAGR (NextMSC). BIM adoption is ~75% on commercial projects but only ~30% on residential. Federal mandate: all GSA projects >$5M require BIM. 8 states have adopted BIM requirements for public projects. The gap is BIM-to-reality: models are created in design but rarely updated during construction or used in operations. OpenSpace (360-degree photo capture, 2M+ captures) and Doxel (AI progress tracking, claims 'visual intelligence') are proving the computer vision approach. A digital twin platform that maintains BIM-to-field synchronization throughout construction and into facility operations creates a $50K-$500K value proposition per commercial project (reducing rework costs that average $31.3B/year in the US per NIST). The lifecycle operations market (building management using the as-built digital twin) extends the TAM into facilities management ($1.1T globally).
models.falsification_criteria: If Autodesk closes the BIM-to-twin gap internally with ACC features, eliminating the integration opportunity. If BIM adoption stalls below 40% in residential (removing the largest sub-segment). If construction firms reject the ongoing data capture requirements (too much field effort for perceived benefit). If digital twin costs don't compress -- currently requires expensive hardware and labor to capture.

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $8.5B (AI/analytics layer on BIM + digital twin for construction by 2030)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup opportunity is in the analytics/intelligence layer on top of BIM, not BIM authoring itself (Autodesk's moat). Doxel and OpenSpace have proven willingness to pay. Path to $200M ARR by serving 2,000 large commercial/infrastructure projects at $100K average.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: ACV $50K-$500K for commercial/infrastructure. $5K-$20K for mid-market. Gross margins 70-80%. Hardware capture costs declining (LiDAR on iPhone, $500 360-cameras vs $5K+ 5 years ago). Professional services component ~20% of revenue.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: Sales cycle 6-18 months for enterprise. BIM mandates create regulatory pull. Owner/developer mandates flow to GCs which flow to subs (top-down adoption). IIJA infrastructure spending creates 5-year demand runway.
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Training data from thousands of scanned projects creates accuracy advantage. BIM model library for clash detection. Integration depth with Autodesk, Trimble, Bentley ecosystems. Switching costs once embedded in project workflows.

Commercial vehicle telematics market $61.5B (2024) to $130.1B (2030) at 13.8% CAGR. 15.5M registered commercial vehicles in the US. Fleet maintenance costs average $15,000/truck/year; predictive maintenance reduces unplanned downtime 25-40%.

cla.rationale: Fleet management is a mature category with established players: Samsara ($933M ARR, $22B market cap), Motive ($600M+ ARR), Geotab (3.9M subscribers), Trimble, Omnitracs/Solera. However, the PREDICTIVE MAINTENANCE layer is still nascent -- most telematics platforms do GPS tracking and ELD compliance but weak on AI-driven maintenance prediction. The opportunity is to build the AI layer that sits on top of telematics data (from any provider) and delivers predictive maintenance, fuel optimization, and driver coaching insights. MO is 6 because Samsara and Motive are expanding into AI analytics. VD is 7 because average fleet spends $150-500K/year on maintenance, and reducing unplanned downtime saves $10-30K per truck annually.

models.deep_dive_evidence: 15.5M US commercial vehicles. Average maintenance cost $15,000/truck/year ($232B total fleet maintenance market). Unplanned downtime costs $448-760 per truck per day. Predictive maintenance reduces unplanned breakdowns 25-40% and extends component life 20-30%. Fleet management leaders: Samsara ($933M ARR, 2025), Motive ($600M+ ARR), Geotab (3.9M subscribers). BUT most existing platforms are telematics-first (GPS, ELD, dashcam) with analytics bolted on. The pure AI maintenance prediction opportunity is greenfield: only 12% of fleets use advanced predictive analytics vs basic threshold alerts. EV fleet transition creates NEW maintenance prediction challenges (battery degradation, charging optimization) that legacy platforms are not built for. The dual-fleet transition (ICE + EV) creates complexity that AI is uniquely positioned to manage.
models.falsification_criteria: If Samsara or Motive successfully builds best-in-class predictive maintenance within their existing platforms (eliminating need for standalone AI layer), the market shrinks to their leftovers. If telematics data remains siloed (each vendor proprietary), a cross-platform AI layer cannot aggregate enough data for superior prediction. If fleet operators remain unwilling to pay premium for predictive vs reactive maintenance (cost culture in trucking is deeply ingrained).

vcr_evidence.tam_estimate: $8.5B by 2030 (AI-powered predictive analytics layer on $70B fleet management market -- targeting 12% premium analytics penetration)
vcr_evidence.capture_analysis: Startup capture feasible in mid-market fleets (50-500 trucks) where Samsara/Motive compete less aggressively. Integration-first approach (work with ANY telematics provider) avoids hardware lock-in problem. Must demonstrate measurable ROI in first 90 days or lose customer.
vcr_evidence.unit_economics: SaaS pricing $25-75/truck/month. 200-truck fleet = $60-180K ARR. Gross margins 80%+. Customer acquisition cost moderated by measurable ROI (provable maintenance cost reduction). Low churn once integrated into maintenance workflow.
vcr_evidence.velocity_indicators: 6-9 month sales cycle for mid-market fleets. Proof of concept with 20-50 trucks, then expand to full fleet. Fastest adoption in temperature-controlled fleets (higher breakdown cost) and long-haul (most expensive downtime).
vcr_evidence.moat_sources: Data compounding: more trucks monitored = better failure prediction models. Cross-fleet learning (anonymized patterns from 10K trucks improve predictions for each individual truck). OEM-specific models (Freightliner vs Peterbilt failure patterns) create depth that generalists cannot replicate.
